description: Electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena.
name: PRINCIPLES II

values.comments:
This course is a continuation of PHYS 101, emphasizing an introduction to classical electricity and magnetism, relativity theory, optics, and the quantum theory of matter. It requires a background in calculus and is suggested for students in a pre-health program. It fulfills the Physical World Sector and has a laboratory co-requisite.

Many students thoroughly enjoyed this class and found the material to be understandable and approachable. A smaller number felt they could not follow the concepts very well.

Students said Professor Cvetic was one of the best physics teachers. She was enthusiastic, really cared about the students, and was always willing to help. She made an effort to know students even though it was a large lecture class. Her lectures were engaging and informative. One student did note that her accent made understanding her difficult at times.

Students found the weekly quizzes to be a pain but acknowledged they helped them understand material. They didn’t find the textbook very helpful, but the practice problems were relatively useful.

This course covers the following subjects: electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena.

Some students found the material to be “somewhat dull.”

Overall, students felt that Professor Thomson was a “very good teacher” who tried hard to “stimulate interest with demos” and “provided very straightforward examples.” However, some students felt Professor Thomson “moved too slowly at times” which was “frustrating.”

The course included weekly quizzes, which students found to be “difficult” but “fair” and “helpful in preparation for exams.” Students found the course to be demanding, citing its “many hours of class per week.” This course satisfies the Physical World sector. It has prerequisites of PHYS150 or PHYS170, and co-requisites of MATH114 and PHYS151 Lab.

Principles of Physics II focuses on Electromagnetism and Radiation. Major topics include: Electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb’s, Ampere’s, and Faraday’s laws; Maxwell’s equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena. This course fulfills the Physical World sector requirement.

One student felt that this was a “great course that will help me later on in schooling.”

A couple of students felt that Professor Lipeles was a “very good lecturer” and “loves what he teaches.” However, one student felt that lectures were “a bit hard to follow” and sometimes seemed “repetitive.”

One student believed that the quizzes were “pretty tricky.”

*6 respondents.
